title: Will Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez win New York's 14th Congressional District Democratic primary?
possible_answers: Yes, and she will win a majority of votes
Yes, and she will win a plurality of votes
correct_answer: Yes, and she will win a majority of votes
preds: AOC is quite popular within the NY 14th, but in an closed primary, turnout will be key. As we saw in 2016, people can quite easily become complacent. The longer lockdown NY experienced may encourage more people to get out to vote. The $2M that MCC raised is a shot across the bows, but it is highly unlikely to be enough. Best guess would be AOC 53%, MCC 39%.

Lowering my probability a bit of her winning a majority of the votes, as she has been doing a lot of TV commercials in the area, which makes me think that she has some real concerns about not winning the primary. Thus, while I think she is going to win the primary, I do think the majority is in question.

Hello everyone! I just discovered GJO a few days ago. I'm happy to be here! I chose my first forecast based solely on the criteria of "ending soonest" and oh boy did I pick a doozy! On first inspection here, I found the overwhelming prevalence of "0% No" forecasts to be puzzling. I've been working my way through the training & master class here, and based on what I've been learning, I did not expect to see *any* 100% or 0% forecasts once I started participating ... How can there be such certainty? I suspect that AOC's national status as a media darling may be clouding judgement here, along with some potential political biases in her favor from participants. I started digging for information that could lead fellow forecasters to such absolute certainty, along with information supporting even a slight possibility of "No". It was a challenge to sift through all the strong emotion on social media, and biased news outlets attacking either AOC or her main competition, Michelle Caruso-Cabrera. After a couple hours of research, I decided that, not only is there little particularly strong evidence of a certain win by AOC, there is evidence against certainty in that A) Her support within her local district is not nearly as unanimous as the national conversation would have me believe, and B) Voter turnout is likely to be even lower than in 2018, because of a combination of COVID and overconfidence in the outcome. In 2018, AOC delivered a major upset by defeating incumbent Joseph Crowley in the primary. However, voter turnout was only ~11% of eligible voters. With fewer than 30,000 votes total, AOC won by a margin of only 4,000 votes, in a district with over 200,000 registered Democrats. My intuition is that turnout may be even lower than 30,000 this time. There will almost certainly be AOC supporters and detractors alike who stay home because they're convinced she has it in the bag, and don't want to risk the polls during the pandemic. https://ballotpedia.org/New_York%27s_14th_Congressional_District Further research for the case against an assured AOC victory led me to a poll from June 2019, conducted by an anti-AOC PAC. To be taken with a grain of salt owing to their obviously biased agenda; they found that, within AOC's 14th Congressional District, "41.73% of her district is unfamiliar with Rep. AOC ... She has a more than 2:1 ratio of unfavorable (50.88%) to favorable (21.37%) in public opinion ... Only 8.91% were opposed to Amazon coming to the district, while 36.01% supported the Amazon HQ deal ... Only 10.75% thought she had their best interests in mind in quashing the Amazon deal - 32.60% said she didn't. ... 33.44% are ready to vote against her, and only 13.30% would vote for her." https://www.stoptheaoc.com/ - Anti-AOC PAC who conducted the poll https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/washington-secrets/poll-aoc-unliked-untrusted-unwanted-in-her-own-ny-district - Washington Examiner article about the poll https://www.allsides.com/news-source/washington-examiner  - AllSides.com analysis of Washington Examiner as a right-leaning publication Digging through the recent Twitter feeds of both AOC and her challenger MCC reveals toxic sentiment against both players. It appears that most of the social media engagement is from people outside the 14th district, but it does reveal that there is nothing like unanimous support for AOC, or against MCC. https://twitter.com/AOC https://twitter.com/MCaruso_Cabrera Given the above key points, as well as all the other fragments of information I found, I believe this contest will be far more of a craps shoot than most people realize. So, though I do think it's more likely than not she will win, it's not clear at all whether it will be by plurality or majority, and I will not be surprised in the least if we see an upset *of* AOC in 2020, just as we saw an upset *by* AOC in 2018. A final thought after investigating this question: even if she does lose this primary, I do feel confident it will not be the last we see of her on the political stage. A large number of recent articles from media outlets leaning to both sides are speculating that she may seek to upset Sen. Chuck Schumer in the 2022 Senate primary ... stay tuned. 🤓

FWIW, a comment in the linked source claims a 52% approve 23% disapprove poll rating for AOC via Morning Consult. Plus a higher approval rating from district Democrats: 
https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5226/Will-Alexandria-Ocasio-Cortez-win-the-Democratic-primary-for-NY's-14th-District
Strong grassroots support even more energized during COVID-19 economic downturn.
As this district has been majorly democratic and based on the ethnicity votes and the support she got from the last election she will win this one fair and square

She defeated Joseph Crowley in 2018, a true watershed ... fair to say she has enhanced her reputation in the district since. Crowded field makes a majority naturally more difficult, but see a lot of her 57% in 2018 returning and even doing slightly doing better in affluent neighbourhoods.
Her popularity has dipped a bit, but I still see her riding the blue wave to an easy victory.

I was scrolling through the litany of forecasts heavily weighted to the "Yes/Majority" bucket without any rationale. I'd like to acknowledge @timwhite's resolve and echo his concern that the consensus it so disconcerting without compelling arguments to back it up.
Yes. AOC is popular and a phenom in many ways. I don't much evidence to point to majority. Plurality is reasonable and respectable. I just don't know how the crowd is silently making an aggressive push for majority. I'll stick in the ballpark, but at a discount. I'm sure I'll be wrong, but this is a case where all my friends are jumping off a bridge.
I have a theory that the consensus is that we just don't enjoy forecasting this question. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/980801
AOC's popularity , along with the recent crisis will increase the votes she will get.
Incumbents usually win. AOC has a commanding lead in polls.
Hedging toward the consensus. There's not a ton of evidence that her challengers are particularly strong. I think she'll likely stay above 50%.
she is as safe a seat as there is in the House.

The zodiacal releasing is crystal clear - on the day of the election she's in Leo-Sag-Can-Gem. Leo is a peak period for her, Sag contains a benefic, Can contains the benefic of sect / ruler of the general period, and Gem is angular only to a benefic.
She is way too popular in a deep blue district to lose
That’s the sort of world we live in

No solid polling data that I could discover. The WP [1] cites "A poll conducted last month for the campaign by Celinda Lake, who also worked with Ocasio-Cortez in 2018, found the congresswoman’s favorable rating at 79 percent, and with 73 percent support in the primary. " There does seem to be a bit of a fight for the seat, though, based on the latest debate. Bumping the majority up quite a bit. [1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/rep-alexandria-ocasio-cortez-isnt-running-as-a-fire-starter/2020/06/03/05792e7a-a597-11ea-bb20-ebf0921f3bbd_story.html

FWIW: (6/3/20 story excerpt:) "A poll conducted last month for the campaign by Celinda Lake, who also worked with Ocasio-Cortez in 2018, found the congresswoman’s favorable rating at 79 percent, and with 73 percent support in the primary."
https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/rep-alexandria-ocasio-cortez-isnt-running-as-a-fire-starter/2020/06/03/05792e7a-a597-11ea-bb20-ebf0921f3bbd_story.html
All hail the Queen of Queen's. :-D
She is now an established candidate with a clear message and out of the shadows of sponsors.

In the 2018 primary, when she was a much "lesser" name, she won the majority of votes (57%). https://ballotpedia.org/Alexandria_Ocasio-Cortez Although that was a head-to-head match-up and there more candidates going up against her this time, which makes a majority less likely.  However, given her profile, I have to imagine that she is going to get the majority of votes.

No polls to go off of. AOC won 57% of the vote in the 2018 primary. She has the incumbency advantage this time. However, she has a somewhat strong challenger in Caruso-Cabrera (https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/09/chamber-commerce-aoc-primary-challenger-175917), and there are also two other challengers (unless they drop out before June 23). Intuitively, this would push her closer to 50% or even below 50%. I think there's little chance she loses outright, maybe a little under 10%. The question becomes whether this set of challengers takes more than 7% of the vote from her. With no polling yet, it's hard to say. I'll lean toward majority for now. I'm surprised the crowd forecast is so lopsided. Hopefully I'm not missing something...
She has a powerful base who believe she has some powerful ideas on how things can change.
Still no polls available. Holding forecast steady.
She made a recent good that hurts her chances somewhat

I was unable to find any recent polls. A Gardian [1] article gives a very favorable overview, noting that she is well liked, has raised a bunch of money and the voters that know her, like her. [1] https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/feb/17/alexandria-ocasio-cortez-aoc-challengers-election
Hard to seeing a high-profile incumbent losing to such a large field of disparate candidates. She only really needs to beat other Dems to win her seat.
As long as she can mobilize her base, her celebrity should keep her safe.

Her opponents seem to be symbolic, barely meeting minimum requirements to run with little fundraising. She can get support nationwide and not just from her district. She has 4 Democrat challengers, but I don't expect them to get 51% between them. maybe a percentage out or two each.

She has a lot of competition, and is not universally popular within the democratic party, so she may not win a majority. However, she is incredibly well-known and liked, and almost certainly will win.
Too talented a politician and too high profile, without any real scandal. Bet on incumbent in any case
She must be considered a celebrity at this time. American voters have shown that they will vote for celebrities no matter that celebrities' political affiliation.
Her profile is steadily increasing with a high approval rating. Likely to win with majority.
She’s a rock star in the Democratic Party. Also a very hard worker. She’s smart and savvy...
She seems popular,  but is quite radical and not sure who she is up against.  So likely but not definite
AOC is popular in her district and has gained enormous name recognition since her election.  She has garnered outsize influence compared to her experience and seniority.
While Republicans aren't happy with her, I think the majority of her constituents are and she has been getting a lot of press and saying and doing good things.
She is very popular among left-leaning Democrats.
Hedging due to the number of people in the field.
AOC is a superstar. Hard to see how any primary challenge won't fall flat.

A little closer to the 'crowd' forecast for now. Although this House seat generally looks 'safe' for Democrats (https://ballotpedia.org/New_York%27s_14th_Congressional_District_election,_2020#Race_ratings), AOC's sometimes polarizing actions + positions may have helped encourage numerous challengers, from both parties.
..Watching for polling data as we get closer to the primary. https://www.foxnews.com/politics/aocs-competition-meet-the-candidates-running-against-ocasio-cortez

Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (AOC) has the biggest profile among her primary challengers.  According to Ballotpedia, she is the primary candidate with the most money (by a huge margin).  According to Wikipedia, the 14th congressional district of NY has a Hispanic population of 49.80%.  New York uses a closed primary process (where the selection of a party's candidates is limited to registered party members). I have a feeling that the energy and enthusiasm that made AOC win the primary in 2018 are still present this year.  I have a feeling that the Hispanic population of NY's 14th congressional district will overwhelmingly vote for her in the primary.  I am forecasting that AOC will win a majority of votes in NY's 14th congressional district democratic primary.  I will monitor the events until June 23, 2020 and make any adjustments to my forecast if necessary. Sources:
https://ballotpedia.org/New_York%27s_14th_Congressional_District_election,_2020_(June_23_Democratic_primary) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York's_14th_congressional_district
She is a strong incumbent, makes news frequently, and has established a donor base outside of her district.

The mere fact that despite the uphill battle, AOC was able to win the majority in 2018 against a popular incumbent candidate speaks volumes as to popular she was in the 14th district. Moreover, she has cultivated a huge presence on both the federal and international stage, marking her as an important figure in american and international politics. the importance of which is not lost on the voters of NY14. Finally, NY14 has already indicated that not only is it a deep blue district it is also progressive district and there is no progressive candidate that can challenge AOC and there just aren't enough moderate voters to win a majority, plus the challengers will likely just split the votes among themselves without touching AOC's solid base and its highly likely that some will drop out before the election, making a plurality even less likely than it already inconceivably is.
Won a majority against the incumbent last time. Should win an easy majority again. Will walk it unless she gets hit by a bus.
AOC has established herself as a power in her district
I think there is a viable alternative with more political savvy that can unseat her.

Outside view: "Going back to 1996, if the incumbent decided to run in the 14th district, they won, apart from in 2018 (11/12 times = 92%)" @KitsonJ. Base rate of 92% for first two buckets.  Inside view:
- 2018 primary: won 56.7% of the vote [1] 
- 5 Democratic challengers: "Ocasio-Cortez’s most coherent Democratic challenger to date is former longtime CNBC correspondent and anchor Michelle Caruso-Cabrera. Caruso-Cabrera, who published a book in 2011 called You Know I’m Right: More Prosperity, Less Government, is a skeptic of big government and a proponent of free markets. Caruso-Cabrera is a relatively recent Democratic party member who registered her candidacy last week, appear to be preparing a more serious challenge as she seeks to take on Ocasio-Cortez in the Democratic primary.
“Caruso-Cabrero is as wild a card as AOC was two years ago,” said Sheinkopf. “Caruso-Cabrero is likely to lead a spirited challenge and could be very competitive." [2]
- Endorsed by Sanders, frontrunner for presidential Democratic primary
- Netflix documentary in 2019 may have raised awareness for voters that did not know about her [1]
- Big criticism from challengers is that she opposed bringing an Amazon headquarters to NYC, losing 25k potential jobs. [3] [4] 
- $3.4 million raised [2]
- Favorability April 2019: "Fifty-two percent of the freshman congresswoman’s registered constituents in The Bronx and the north-central portion of Queens view her favorably, compared to 33 percent who view her unfavorably. Fifty-nine percent of voters [in the Sienna poll] say that they are proud to have Ocasio-Cortez representing the district, and 61 percent agree that while many of her ideas on the economy, climate or healthcare may not become law soon, they think she is moving us towards a more fair and just society." [5]  I think inside view supports AOC being reelected, but Caruso-Cabrero is a wild card who will try and resonate with more moderate Democratic voters. Lowering base rate to 80% for first two buckets. Majority/Plurality: Unsure how to assign probabilities for majority/plurality split because I could not find any data on Democratic primaries, I believe because the incumbent has been unopposed. I think Caruso-Cabrero is the only real challenger, so if the race is only between the two of them, the winner will win majority (>50%). Assigning 90% probability to majority (80% * 90% = 72%). Crowd: 72%, 23%, 5% [1] https://ballotpedia.org/Alexandria_Ocasio-Cortez
[2] https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/feb/17/alexandria-ocasio-cortez-aoc-challengers-election
[3] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/18/nyregion/aoc-2020-opponents.html
[4] https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2020/feb/17/alexandria-ocasio-cortez-launches-reelection-campa/
[5] https://www.rollcall.com/2019/04/10/ocasio-cortez-still-popular-in-district-despite-being-unfavorable-nationally/

There are a lot of challengers, but, as far as I can tell, none who would cannibalise AOC's vote (i.e. challengers from the left), and if there were she'd have a very strong squeeze message. 
That said, the many horses in the race would perhaps leave a chance that she wouldn't have an outright majority (the last Primary being a two horse race as I understand it, though I'm not sure the previous incumbent was notably bad).
Of course, I'll need to update this depending on how the campaigns seem to be shaking out.
Based on last election data. Nothing significant has changed.

Not many polls yet, but a 2019 one indicated overall 'favorable' for AOC (https://sunnysidepost.com/ocasio-cortez-viewed-favorably-by-majority-of-voters-in-her-district-poll).  NYT says a Republican has not won this seat in 50 years, and that AOC has raised a good amount of money. (https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/18/nyregion/aoc-2020-opponents.html) AOC won the 2018 general election for the district with 78% of the vote. 
(https://ballotpedia.org/New_York%27s_14th_Congressional_District_election,_2020) Leaving the second question 'bin' up a little higher for now mainly as so many candidates are running.
Long time to go, but she is very popular - very likely to win. But possible others race against her, making it a split to plurality.
She is very loved in her district..intensity wins.
No democrat can get left of her. Her district will be fine with her; it would be a stupid challenge at this time

Obviously we are very far out. But given her profile and her campaign fundraising it is almost impossible to see her unseated. The main question is how many people run against her as that may split the vote and lead to only a plurality. However, given her dominant position, it seems unlikely anyone will take her on.
AOC is a force in her district. She will probably hang around in the political spectrum for quite awhile.

Going back to 1996, if the incumbent decided to run in the 14th district, they won, apart from in 2018 (11/12 times) with AOC winning the primary in a shock in 2018. This question is not asking about the congressional race in November, but the primary race. AOC has a large amount of cash on hand to fight the race, whereas her democratic opponents have in some cases raised $0.
